metadata.title: Turning hazardous red mud into useful catalysts for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides

[e]. reaction liquid mixture from the hot filtration experiment (Entry 5), 12 h Turning hazardous red mud into useful catalysts for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides Dilong Chen Yuxiao Ding ⁎ Chungu Xia Lin He ⁎ Yanwei Cao ⁎ State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics (LICP), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics (LICP) Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics (LICP), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. With the rapid development of the aluminium industry, the output of waste by-products (red mud) increases over time. Although continuous efforts have been devoted to dealing with this hazardous waste, the universal utilization of red mud accounts for only 15% of the total. Therefore, development of green and sustainable technologies with which to dispose of red mud is regarded worldwide as an urgent requirement. Herein, a facile utilization of the bases in hazardous red mud to catalyze the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides is reported. This catalytic system can achieve 99% conversion of amines with 100% selectivity for N-formamides. Gram-scale preparation of useful formamides, such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N-formylmorpholine was also successfully accomplished. Further investigation revealed that a free alkaline ingredient in red mud is the active center for this transformation. This work provides an economical and environmentally benign solution to the use of the waste red mud, and also greatly promotes the potential application to catalysis of materials derived from red mud. Graphical Abstract Water soluble alkaline salts extracted from red mud as a robust catalyst for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides with CO is demonstrated. The facile and sustainable catalytic system provided the excellent reactivity for N-formamides in good yields and was suitable for preparing important N-formamides in gram-scales. Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Red mud Formamide Base Carbonylation Amines Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Red mud (RM) is an alkaline waste material, with pH = 10 ∼ 12, that is produced by the aluminum industry [1–4]. The amount of RM ranges from 1.5 ∼ 2.5 tons per ton of aluminum produced, and the annual global output of RM is about 120 million tons per year [1]. In contrast, its average worldwide utilization rate is low; the rate at which RM is utilized in China, which produces more than 70% of the world's aluminum, is only about 4% [1]. This situation has received much attention due to its negative and harmful effect on the environment. Thus, the development of new methods to deal with hazardous RM waste is key to the long-term sustainability of aluminum production. The abundant elements and relatively high surface area of components of RM could potentially support its use as a catalyst or a support. RM-based catalysts have shown promising catalytic performance in a variety of reactions, including hydrogenation [5–8], hydro-liquefaction [9], hydrogen production [10, 11], selective catalytic reduction [2], degradation and oxidation [12–15]. Many alkaline components are discharged during the preparation of red mud-based catalysts [11, 15-18]. Bases are also efficient catalysts for various transformation, such as transesterification, hydrolysis, depolymerization of lignin and aldol condensation [19–23]. With its typical alkalinity, RM could also efficiently catalyze various base-catalyzed transformation, but studies of this problem remain quite limited. Formamides are important N-containing carbonyl compounds that are common in biologically active natural products, as synthons for organic syntheses and as versatile solvents [24–29]. NaOMe-catalyzed Carbonylation of amines to form N-formamides is a commercial process that is used for the production of N-formamides and is an atom economic reaction without any by-product. For this process, the E factor = 0 and the atom utilization = 100% [30]. CO can also be considered a renewable feedstock which is based on biomass and CO2 reduction [31–33]. Thus, the utilization of CO in the construction of formamides is a very positive factor in sustainable chemistry. In 2015, Wu et al. reported a carbonylation of amines to formamides using inorganic bases as catalysts, such as M(OH)x, MxCO3, and M xPO4 of Group IA/IIA [30]. Meanwhile, Kim et al. reported the K3PO4-catalyzed carbonylation of amines to formamides [34]. More recently, Jang et al. found that organic bases, such as 1,5,7-triazabicyclo [4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD), were also effective catalysts for this transformation [35]. Beyond base catalysts, carbonylation of amines to formamides has also been intensively studied using metal catalysts, such as Ru [36–38], Rh [39, 40], Pd-Co [41], Au [42–44], Cu [45, 46], Zn [47], Fe [48] or Ni [49], N-Heterocyclic carbenes [50], NaIO4 [51] and ionic liquids [52]. Although these catalysts were effective for the synthesis of formamides, most of them involve noble metals or high purity reagents as catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, no reaction of this sort using alkaline industrial waste has been published. More importantly, the application of waste resources as catalysts in chemical transformations is highly challenging but valuable [53–57]. Herein, we report a facile utilization of the hazardous RM wastes as a catalyst for the carbonylation of amines leading to N-formamides (Scheme 1 ). In view of the utility of alkaline industrial waste as a potential catalyst, the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides using CO as a C1 source with RM-derived catalysts is valuable and sustainable. In the presence of RM-sourced components with different amines, various formamides were obtained in satisfactory yields. The utilization of waste materials and the reduced adverse environmental effects of RM associated with the waste base catalysts leaves it well suited to the carbonylation of amines producing N-formamides. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Considerations Red mud (RM) is obtained from Zibo City, Shandong, China. All commercial reagents are ordered from Sinopharm, Adamas-beta®, Energy chemical, Alfa, Aldrich. Synthetic air and carbon monoxide (≥ 99.95%) in cylinders are purchased from Liquid Air. Unless otherwise stated, commercial reagents are used without purification. 2.2 Dealkalization of red mud 2.2.1 Water washing on dealkalization of red mud Red mud (10 g) is mixed with deionized water (200 mL) in a beaker, the mixture is then stirred vigorously for 2 h, and then solid-liquid separation by the centrifugation. The solid phase is re-mixed with deionized water (200 mL) in a beaker for the several times to obtain the dealkalization of red mud (RM-W). Finally, the water-soluble salts (WSS) are obtained through evaporation of the lixivium (liquid part). 2.2.2 CO2 assisted dealkalization of red mud Red mud (10 g) is mixed with deionized water (100 mL) in a flask under 1 bar CO2, the mixture was then stirred vigorously for 24 h, and then solid-liquid separation by the centrifugation to obtain the dealkalization of red mud (RM-CO2). 2.2.3 Acid assisted dealkalization of red mud Red mud (10 g) is mixed with deionized water (100 mL) in a flask. After stirring for 5 min, 150 mL of 6 M HNO3 solution is added. The sample is digested at 70°C on a water-bath heater for 2 h. Then, ammonium hydroxide is added dropwise into the mixture until the solution pH around 8. The precipitate is separated by the centrifugation to obtain the dealkalization of red mud (RM-A). 2.3 General procedure for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides In a typical reaction, the 2 mg of WSS or 50 mg of red mud catalyst is weighed into a 10 mL reactor containing a stir bar. The required amounts of morpholine (0.5 mmol), methanol (2 mL) is added. At room temperature, the batch reactor is charged with 2.0 MPa of CO. The mixture is stirred at 130 °C for 12 h. Afterwards, the autoclave is cooled to room temperature and the pressure is carefully released. The products of the reaction are analyzed by gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7890A) and GC-MS spectrometry (MS, Shimadzu). Chromatography purifications are carried out over diatomite with ethyl acetate as eluent. Analytical data of literature-reported compounds are in accord with reported data. 1H, 13C NMR spectra are recorded on AVANCE NEO 400MHZ NMR spectrometer (Bruker). Carbonylation of other amines to N-formamides is carried out with similar procedure. 2.4 Characterization The chemical composition of samples is recorded on of X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (Thermo Scientific ARL PERFORM'X). The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns are collected by a D8 ADVANCE X-ray with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405Å). The sodium contents are analyzed by ICP-OES (Agilent 720ES). 3 Results and discussion RM was obtained from the aluminum plant of Shandong, China. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis showed that it contains Fe2O3 (41.1%), Al2O3 (19.3%), SiO2 (19.9%), Na2O (14.4%), TiO2 (6.2%), CaO (0.6%). Analysis by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) showed that the raw RM contains 9.4 wt% of Na. Mixing 0.1 g raw RM and 1 mL H2O produced a liquid with a pH of 10.6, demonstrating the high alkalinity of the RM (Table 1 ). Such results suggest that the RM, in specifically alkaline ingredients, could serve as a catalyst for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides. In a preliminary study of the catalytic process, morpholine (1a) was subjected to carbonylation producing formamides from RM at 130 °C under 2 MPa of CO with methanol as solvent. When the loading of RM increased, the yield of N-formylmorpholine (2a) improved to 99% (Table 2 , Entry 3). The yield of N-formylmorpholine decreased to 44% in the second run (Table 2 Entry 4) and hot filtration experiments confirmed that the active components were leached out during the first N-formylmorpholine synthesis (Table 2, Entries 7-8). Based on these results, dealkalization of RM by water, CO2 or acid was conducted to obtain the dealkalized RM, denoted as RM-W, RM-CO2 and RM-A respectively (Table 1). The catalytic activity of these samples was evaluated. In a reaction under same conditions, RM-W gave a yield of 20% (Table 2 Entry 7); RM-CO2 gave a yield of 11% (Table 2 Entry 8); RM-A gave a yield of 4% (Table 2 Entry 9). These results indicate that alkaline anions, especially free alkaline compounds are critical to the reaction. We then enriched the lixivium obtained from leaching after washing it with water to obtain the water-soluble salts (WSS). With the help of X-ray diffraction (XRD), the WSS was found to be a mixture of NaOH, Na2CO3 and NaHCO3. As shown in Table 1 and Fig. 1 , it contained ∼33.5 wt.% of Na elements. The reaction afforded N-formylmorpholine in 99% yield with 2 mg of WSS catalysts (Table 2 Entry 10). Although the activity of high purity reagents (NaOH, Na2CO3) as catalysts are slightly higher than WSS, the cost of WSS is much cheaper than those purity reagents (Table S1). The scope of solvents for the carbonylation of morpholine was investigated using ethanol, i-propanol, t-butanol, THF, dioxane and toluene. None of them had an effect on the reaction comparative to that of methanol (Table 2 Entry 11-16), suggesting that methanol may also be involved in the catalytic process. To expand the generality and scope of the WSS in its catalysis of the carbonylation of amines, 0.5 mmol of different substrates were tested with WSS to form N-formamides under the optimal reaction conditions, and the results are shown in Scheme 2 . Piperidines containing methyl (2c, 2d), methoxyl (2e), cyano (2f), phenyl (2g), benzyl (2h), piperidyl (2i), hydroxy (2j), carbinol (2k) and 1,4-dioxa (2l) substituents with various functional groups at different positions all affect the reaction minimally. These substituents generally exhibited excellent yields from 75 - 91%. A series of piperazines, such as 4-methyl (2m), 4-ethyl (2n) and 4-formyl (2o) perform moderately in conversion to the corresponding N-formamides with the related yields ranging from 68 to 99%. Other representative linear or cyclic secondary amines such as thiomorpholine (2p), pyrrolidine (2q), dimethylamine (2r), N-allylmethylamine (2t), N-methyl-benzylamine (2u) and 2-(methylamino) ethanol (2v) also produced the desired N-formamides in reasonable yields. Primary aliphatic amines are also well tolerated in the carbonylation reaction, giving the related N-formamides (2w-2aa) in excellent yields. However, aromatic amines, with the exception of 4-aminopyridine (2bb) were nearly inactive in this transformation. The scope of the double carbonylation of diamines forming the corresponding diformamides was also investigated, and the results are shown in Scheme 3 . The double carbonylation of aliphatic primary diamines, including ethanediamine, 1,3-propanediamine, 1,6-diaminohexane, 4,4′-diaminodicyclohexyl methane and 1,2-diaminocyclohexane gave the related diformamides (2cc-2gg) in 67-99% yield. Aliphatic secondary diamines, such as piperazine and N1,N6 -dimethylhexane-1,6-diamine were carbonylated with CO to give good yields of the desired diformamides (2o, 2hh). Aliphatic primary/secondary diamines, like N1 -methylpropane-1,3-diamine and 4-(amino-methyl)piperidine also gave the diformamides with excellent yield in 91% (2ii) and 77% (2jj) yield. To illustrate the synthetic utility of the reaction, the WSS could easily be scaled up to prepare some important N-formamides. For example, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is a versatile solvent, but also a multipurpose building block widely used in synthetic chemistry. The size of the DMF market was valued at USD 665.87 million in 2020 and is projected to reach USD 1123 million by 2028. When dimethylamine (40 mmol) was subjected to a pressure of CO in the presence of 20 mg of WWS, 2.9 g of DMF was obtained. In the same way, 4.6 g of N-formylmorpholine was also obtained (Scheme 4 ). In order to understand the possible mechanism of the WWS catalyzing carbonylation of amines to N-formamides, NMR was used to monitor the change in the reaction components before and after the base-catalyzed methanol carbonylation. From the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture, two new signals appeared at δ = 8.45 and 8.04 ppm, indicating the generation of sodium formate and methyl formate after the reaction. From 13C NMR spectrum of the mixture, two new signals also appeared at δ = 170 ppm and δ = 163 ppm agreed with this result (Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, from gas chromatography (GC) spectrum of the mixture after carbonylation of morpholine producing N-formamides, a trace amount of methyl formate was observed (SI, Fig. S3-S6). Based on the experimental observations, two possible reaction pathways for this process could be envisioned. The first one is that Na ion in RM or collected from the lixivium, or leachate dissolves in methanol to form sodium methoxide (NaOMe), and this is followed by the carbonylation of methanol, generating methyl formate. Then nucleophilic attack of the amine on methyl formate forms the N-formamide. The other pathway is carbonylation of sodium hydroxide, producing sodium formate, which then catalyzes the carbonylation of amines to N-formamide in methanol (Scheme 5 ). 4 Conclusion In summary, carbonylation of amines to N-formamides has been demonstrated using the RM based materials as effective catalysts. Compared with traditional metal and high purity base catalysts, the use of waste base in hazardous RM as a catalyst is of interest due to the environmental aspects of recycling industrial waste. With the RM-based catalyst, a variety of primary and secondary amines were carbonylated with CO to give desired N-formamides in good yield with excellent selectivity. The carbonylation of diamines and the gram-scale preparation of useful N-formamides have both also been implemented. From the perspective of green & sustainable chemistry, waste base in hazardous RM could be used legitimately as catalysts for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides with excellent atom economy. coredata.dc:description: With the rapid development of the aluminium industry, the output of waste by-products (red mud) increases over time. Although continuous efforts have been devoted to dealing with this hazardous waste, the universal utilization of red mud accounts for only 15% of the total. Therefore, development of green and sustainable technologies with which to dispose of red mud is regarded worldwide as an urgent requirement. Herein, a facile utilization of the bases in hazardous red mud to catalyze the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides is reported. This catalytic system can achieve 99% conversion of amines with 100% selectivity for N-formamides. Gram-scale preparation of useful formamides, such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N-formylmorpholine was also successfully accomplished. Further investigation revealed that a free alkaline ingredient in red mud is the active center for this transformation. This work provides an economical and environmentally benign solution to the use of the waste red mud, and also greatly promotes the potential application to catalysis of materials derived from red mud.
coredata.dc:title: Turning hazardous red mud into useful catalysts for the carbonylation of amines to N-formamides
